description.narrative: Establecer un marco binacional para el manejo integrado de la cuenca del rio Artibonito para el 2012, que promueva reformas detalladas basadas en el ecosistema
capital of a political entity

Establish a binational framework for integrated management of the Artibonito watershed by 2012 that will promote comprehensive ecosystembased reforms demonstrations and investments and lay the bases for longterm environmental functionality and socioeconomic stability

Increase in freshwater flow m3sec at the Peligre Dam
Increase in area under permanent tree cover ha in the entire basin
Ecosystem diversity increase in area with native tree species cover
Reduction in sediment load tonneshayear at Peligre dam site

comment.narrative:
Extensive deforestation and harmful agricultural practices in the upper areas of the watershed have resulted in severe soil erosion and sedimentation of waterways and reduction in freshwater output
Baselines are as follows
Freshwater flow 45 m3sec
Area under tree cover in the Artibonite 1999 levels 120000 ha
Native tree species nearly extirpated or highly threatened in some areas in the watershed Baseline will be determined during the TDA
Sediment load at Peligre Dam site120 tonneshayear 2006
Baselines and targets by subwatersheds will be validated during the TDA process

Freshwater flow No decrease from current level of 45 m3sec and optimally increase to 65 m3sec by 2030 to meet needs of future population
Area under permanent tree cover
DR Increase by new cover above baseline by 20000 ha by year 2030 and 40000 ha by 2050
Haiti Increase in area under new cover by 30000 ha by year 2030 and by 60000 ha by 2050
20 of area under new cover to be with native species target to be refined during TDA
50 reduction in sediment load in Peligre dam site from 120 tonneshayear to 60 tonneshayear by year 2030

Work on stress reduction indicators was completed prior to June 2014
Both the SAP and the National Action Plans include new indicators for future watershed development These promote increase in tree cover and improved pasture by 40000 ha in binational watersheds The goal is to establish the protection of the aforementioned and to control sedimentation going to the Péligre dam and to improve coverage by 1000 ha per year in the highest areas of each country This target neutralizes the effect of deforestation to present levels
The project was successful in measuring the water quality and flow in the Dominican Republic In spite of equipping the Haitian Ministry of Environment for this task No report was filed
Water flow overall for Haiti was estimated with support of the project by Artelia 2013
The watershed investment program includes includes investments in the infrastructure needed to measure water flow in Haiti

Freshwater flow No decrease from current level of 45 m3sec and optimally increase to 65 m3sec by 2030 to meet needs of future population
Area under permanent tree cover
DR Increase by new cover above baseline by 20000 ha by year 2030 and 40000 ha by 2050
Haiti Increase in area under new cover by 30000 ha by year 2030 and by 60000 ha by 2050
20 of area under new cover to be with native species target to be refined during TDA
50 reduction in sediment load in Peligre dam site from 120 tonneshayear to 60 tonneshayear by year 2030

Work on stress reduction indicators was completed prior to June 2014
Both the SAP and the National Action Plans include new indicators for future watershed development These promote increase in tree cover and improved pasture by 40000 ha in binational watersheds The goal is to establish the protection of the aforementioned and to control sedimentation going to the Péligre dam and to improve coverage by 1000 ha per year in the highest areas of each country This target neutralizes the effect of deforestation to present levels
The project was successful in measuring the water quality and flow in the Dominican Republic In spite of equipping the Haitian Ministry of Environment for this task No report was filed
Water flow overall for Haiti was estimated with support of the project by Artelia 2013
The watershed investment program includes includes investments in the infrastructure needed to measure water flow in Haiti

description.narrative: Beneficiaries in pilot project areas report an improvement in standard of living in the form of increased access to ecosystem services and increased commerce within demonstration areas

comment.narrative:
Limited access to water for domestic use and production
84 families in DR target communities with access to fresh water Las lagunas
Producers of peanuts root crops and fruits selling home processed or unprocessed foodstuffs to local markets

1900 families with access to fresh water from 2 water delivery systems and one tubular well by Q8
2000 producers in 8 associations with improved access to markets By Q12
No additional project activity in this indicator

1900 families with access to fresh water from 2 water delivery systems and one tubular well by Q8
2000 producers in 8 associations with improved access to markets By Q12
No additional project activity in this indicator

description.narrative: A Binational Strategic Action Program SAP for the sustainable management of the Artibonite watershed endorsed at highest levels IW SP 3

comment.narrative: No watershedwide planning and management framework for regional cooperation in the management of the Artibonite No watershedwide intervention has ever been undertaken Efforts to address environmental degradation have been fragmented and ultimately unsustainable
Ratification of SAP by relevant Ministries and Secretariats government agencies and key resource user groups by Q 13

A binational framework for integrated management of the watershed was not endorsed by the governments However a nongovernmental framework to promote longterm environmental functionality and socioeconomic stability has been established
The SAP document was completed 100 and successfully negotiated by the governments but not endorsed due to external political factors see Political Risks
The Binational Technical Committee endorsed the SAP document and drafted a declaration of endorsement The binational meeting of the ministers to endorse the SAP was cancelled with no official explanation
The SAP document and declaration are available to the governments for endorsement if the political landscape should change
The SAP defines the political framework for official watershed cooperation between the governments and defines key watershed investments at the binational level see watershed investment plan activity 4
The project was successful in developing the Nationallevel Watershed Management councils that are publicprivate partnerships to promote investments and longterm environmental functionality and socioeconomic stability These are nationallevel structures see outcome 2 The council is officially incorporated in the Dominican Republic and is working independently to incorporate in Haiti with NGO support Since these structures do not depend on government support they may prove to be more effective vehicles for watershed development and not subject to political changes or attitudes
Ratification of SAP by relevant Ministries and Secretariats government agencies and key resource user groups by Q 13

A binational framework for integrated management of the watershed was not endorsed by the governments However a nongovernmental framework to promote longterm environmental functionality and socioeconomic stability has been established
The SAP document was completed 100 and successfully negotiated by the governments but not endorsed due to external political factors see Political Risks
The Binational Technical Committee endorsed the SAP document and drafted a declaration of endorsement The binational meeting of the ministers to endorse the SAP was cancelled with no official explanation
The SAP document and declaration are available to the governments for endorsement if the political landscape should change
The SAP defines the political framework for official watershed cooperation between the governments and defines key watershed investments at the binational level see watershed investment plan activity 4
The project was successful in developing the Nationallevel Watershed Management councils that are publicprivate partnerships to promote investments and longterm environmental functionality and socioeconomic stability These are nationallevel structures see outcome 2 The council is officially incorporated in the Dominican Republic and is working independently to incorporate in Haiti with NGO support Since these structures do not depend on government support they may prove to be more effective vehicles for watershed development and not subject to political changes or attitudes

description.narrative: Outcome 3 Demonstration projects of local economic and sustainable land and water management provide models for upscaling and replication and early SAP implementation
Increase in number of rural households engaged in environmentally sound and sustainable economic activities in the pilot projects area LD SP 1

comment.narrative:
0 Families connected to supply chain for organic fruit products and root crops
In general productive activities are not economically profitable or environmentally sustainable resulting in declining incomes and increasing poverty levels among the watershed population

900 producers marketing through new supply chains by Q12
6000 families have registered business relationships through 4 improved and certified
agribusinesses by Q12
750 families benefit from 12 km of roads repaired by Q8
There were no additional actions during the evaluation period

900 producers marketing through new supply chains by Q12
6000 families have registered business relationships through 4 improved and certified
agribusinesses by Q12
750 families benefit from 12 km of roads repaired by Q8
There were no additional actions during the evaluation period

description.narrative: Improved environmental governance frameworks at local levels in support of ongoing decentralization process in the Dominican Republic

comment.narrative: Divergent and inefficient institutional framework for land and water management at local level in DR Significant technical and financial weaknesses in municipal government and local representation of agencies responsible for land and water management

An institutionally strengthened and decentralized governance framework for land and water resources management and strengthened capacities that will lead to an enabling administrative and regulatory environment
Opportunities for replication in Haiti explored

The pilot project process is 90 complete A Final Report Draft was written
The cost of increasing the governments capacity for environmental management calculated by improving provincial offices was analyzed
A model Plan Municipal de Ordenamiento Territorial that will be a model for the Dominican Government is 80 complete The plan is being completed by the Department of Land Management DGODT in the municipalities of Juan Santiago and Hondo Valle
This plan will provide the methodology and the costs of the structure of the territorial organization for all municipalities in the Artibonite basin The plans are being completed with cofinancing from the European Union
A Technology Assessment and Strengthening of the staff technical capacity from the Provincial Offices of Elías Piña and San Juan de la Maguana was performed The goal was a survey and evaluation of technical skills in handling software for geographic information systems database and capturing environmental data from GPS as well as topographic map understanding and basic cartography The number of trained increased to 34 to benefit more technical staff
3 Provincial Offices San Juan Elias Piña and Dajabón have been equipped 2 Municipal Offices were equipped in turn Restauración and Hondo Valle The latter was possible because of the donation of a building by the Ministry of Agriculture in Hondo Valle The pilot project equipped the Mancommunity of Elias Piña province comprising 13 of the 18 municipal bodies in the basin The Municipal Technical Office OTIMEP of the Mancommunity also serves as the Municipal Environmental Management Unit UGAM Technical support and assistance communications equipment reliable power and training have been provided
3 UGAMs within the basin were equipped and trained Las Matas de Farfán Pedro Santana and Restauración
Three key documents were produced 1 Environmental Characterization of the San Juan province 2 An Environmental Agenda of the San Juan province 3 an Environmental Characterization of the Artibonite basin This process was carried out with the participation of the Dominican Ministry of Environment and other civilian organizations and agencies within the territory As part of the Environmental Agenda the watershed actors pronouncements were shared in relation to the confirmation and completion of the identified environmental problems and the main lines of Action These will form the work agenda of the Provincial Directorates
The Environmental Characterization of the Artibonite basin is therefore the first attempt to transfer the experiences and methods of the Provincial Environmental Characterizations beyond the politicaladministrative and territorial scenario of a province to accomplish an Environmental Characterization under a watershed approach in this case the Artibonite

An institutionally strengthened and decentralized governance framework for land and water resources management and strengthened capacities that will lead to an enabling administrative and regulatory environment
Opportunities for replication in Haiti explored

The pilot project process is 90 complete A Final Report Draft was written
The cost of increasing the governments capacity for environmental management calculated by improving provincial offices was analyzed
A model Plan Municipal de Ordenamiento Territorial that will be a model for the Dominican Government is 80 complete The plan is being completed by the Department of Land Management DGODT in the municipalities of Juan Santiago and Hondo Valle
This plan will provide the methodology and the costs of the structure of the territorial organization for all municipalities in the Artibonite basin The plans are being completed with cofinancing from the European Union
A Technology Assessment and Strengthening of the staff technical capacity from the Provincial Offices of Elías Piña and San Juan de la Maguana was performed The goal was a survey and evaluation of technical skills in handling software for geographic information systems database and capturing environmental data from GPS as well as topographic map understanding and basic cartography The number of trained increased to 34 to benefit more technical staff
3 Provincial Offices San Juan Elias Piña and Dajabón have been equipped 2 Municipal Offices were equipped in turn Restauración and Hondo Valle The latter was possible because of the donation of a building by the Ministry of Agriculture in Hondo Valle The pilot project equipped the Mancommunity of Elias Piña province comprising 13 of the 18 municipal bodies in the basin The Municipal Technical Office OTIMEP of the Mancommunity also serves as the Municipal Environmental Management Unit UGAM Technical support and assistance communications equipment reliable power and training have been provided
3 UGAMs within the basin were equipped and trained Las Matas de Farfán Pedro Santana and Restauración
Three key documents were produced 1 Environmental Characterization of the San Juan province 2 An Environmental Agenda of the San Juan province 3 an Environmental Characterization of the Artibonite basin This process was carried out with the participation of the Dominican Ministry of Environment and other civilian organizations and agencies within the territory As part of the Environmental Agenda the watershed actors pronouncements were shared in relation to the confirmation and completion of the identified environmental problems and the main lines of Action These will form the work agenda of the Provincial Directorates
The Environmental Characterization of the Artibonite basin is therefore the first attempt to transfer the experiences and methods of the Provincial Environmental Characterizations beyond the politicaladministrative and territorial scenario of a province to accomplish an Environmental Characterization under a watershed approach in this case the Artibonite

description.narrative: No water users associations exist in the pilot areas There is limited understanding of opportunities for improving water use efficiency options

comment.narrative: Four water associations formed in Haiti and the DR covering 12 sections 5 in Haiti and 7 in the DR

Statutes of establishment of the associations
Minutes of meetings
There were no additional actions during the evaluation period

Statutes of establishment of the associations
Minutes of meetings
There were no additional actions during the evaluation period

description.narrative: Positive IRR on investments undertaken within model demonstration projects and of investment portfolio

comment.narrative: No systematized local investments to support improved production for local markets in harmony with landscape values

A positive IRR on local investments in sustainable agriculture livestock management or forestry projected
Positive portfolio IRR of 5 above administrative costs and inflation

All projects were closed successfully Final documents for the Verrettes and St Michel Pilots were produced The Environmental governance final report is in progress
Final reports of the Verrettes St Michel and PROBINA projects indicate increases in returns to families in terms of profitability It was determined at the midterm evaluation that IRR was not an appropriate indicator for rural systems

A positive IRR on local investments in sustainable agriculture livestock management or forestry projected
Positive portfolio IRR of 5 above administrative costs and inflation

All projects were closed successfully Final documents for the Verrettes and St Michel Pilots were produced The Environmental governance final report is in progress
Final reports of the Verrettes St Michel and PROBINA projects indicate increases in returns to families in terms of profitability It was determined at the midterm evaluation that IRR was not an appropriate indicator for rural systems

description.narrative: Increase in area under sustainable land management new land under permanent cover in the form of permanent cover trees treecrops through demonstration projects LD SP 1

comment.narrative:
Productive activities are inconsistent with local topography and ecosystem functionality resulting in severe erosion and land degradation and threats to rural livelihoods Anecdotal evidence indicates declines in soil fertility and crop yields
The area under permanent land cover in the form of trees and tree crops in the pilot sites is 12061 ha
No methodology or baseline measurements for erosion on local farming systems exist

By Q12 a 5 increase in new land committed to permanent tree cover trees tree crops within the pilot projects from 39 to 44 cover assuming no other significant losses
Targets are
1720 ha reforested or rehabilitated with sustainable forestry and agroforestry systems or for protection bringing the area under permanent tree cover to 13781 ha
Haiti 500000 woody trees planted on 450 ha for sustainable harvest and for protection
120000 fruit and coffee trees planted on 500 ha for production
DR Hondo Valle 50000 shade coffee trees planted to rehabilitate 200 ha of coffee plantations
35000 fruit trees planted to establish agroforestry plantations on over 145 ha
100000 woody trees planted on 90 ha for sustainable harvest and for protection
DR Las Lagunas
35000 fruit trees planted to establish 84 agroforestry plantations on over 145 ha
100000 woody trees planted on 90 ha for sustainable harvest and for protection
990 ha of soil conservation systems established in Haiti DR 500 ha in Haiti 490 ha in DR
Methodology tested and baseline established for erosion measurements in pilot sites While the target is to reduce erosion by 50 in the watershed this will be validated or adjusted through the pilot projects
There were no increases in cover noted in the evaluation period by the Verrette subproject

description.narrative: Outcome 1 Comprehensive analysis of watershed issues provides a sound basis for prioritization of transboundary problems and agreement on management objectives
Accurate model of the availability of ecosystem provisioning services for future population and demographic scenarios developed

comment.narrative: No consolidated information on future demand for water food wood and other ecosystem services
A 50year projection of wood water and soil demand and availability projections stratified by decade for future population and migration scenarios by Q7

Future scenarios for water in the Artibonite watershed were published as part of the economic model to determine the optimum investments in the watershed Haitis lack of water data forced the contractors to deduce the amounts by interpolating from INDRHIs data sets The accuracy of the model is open to scrutiny but the model was helpful in determining the key infrastructure needed in the Artibonite
The project also documented mining reserves from private sector data and tested for heavy metals in water to establish a baseline to gauge changes in the event of future mining activity
The project also documented sustainable energy potential and the need to offset vegetative carbon as a source of fuel in Haiti for its undue pressure on the regions cover and water yield
A 50year projection of wood water and soil demand and availability projections stratified by decade for future population and migration scenarios by Q7

Future scenarios for water in the Artibonite watershed were published as part of the economic model to determine the optimum investments in the watershed Haitis lack of water data forced the contractors to deduce the amounts by interpolating from INDRHIs data sets The accuracy of the model is open to scrutiny but the model was helpful in determining the key infrastructure needed in the Artibonite
The project also documented mining reserves from private sector data and tested for heavy metals in water to establish a baseline to gauge changes in the event of future mining activity
The project also documented sustainable energy potential and the need to offset vegetative carbon as a source of fuel in Haiti for its undue pressure on the regions cover and water yield

description.narrative: Stakeholder implementation plan enables effective dialogue between upper and lower watershed

comment.narrative: No mechanism to facilitate stakeholder communication between distant areas of the watershed or transnationally

1st consolidated stakeholder dialogue that facilitates the development of governance structures providing a forum for stakeholder issues of from all geographic regions within the watershed on land management tradeoffs and ecosystem services by Q6

The watershed management councils in the Dominican Republic and Haiti are active and provide the best opportunity to followthrough on the national action plans and also pressure the governments to meet and sign a binational strategic action program
In the Dominican Republic the Council was incorporated as a nonprofit Association with regular board meetings Visit wwwalianzaartibonitoorg The council developed an electronic membership system accessible at the website which will also be the future platform for accessing project documents in addition to the government and UNDP
In Haiti the council is in the process of legal incorporation with NGO support

1st consolidated stakeholder dialogue that facilitates the development of governance structures providing a forum for stakeholder issues of from all geographic regions within the watershed on land management tradeoffs and ecosystem services by Q6

The watershed management councils in the Dominican Republic and Haiti are active and provide the best opportunity to followthrough on the national action plans and also pressure the governments to meet and sign a binational strategic action program
In the Dominican Republic the Council was incorporated as a nonprofit Association with regular board meetings Visit wwwalianzaartibonitoorg The council developed an electronic membership system accessible at the website which will also be the future platform for accessing project documents in addition to the government and UNDP
In Haiti the council is in the process of legal incorporation with NGO support

description.narrative: A Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis TDA completed and approved

comment.narrative: Outdated and incomplete biophysical and socioeconomic information on the watershed inadequate understanding of the transboundary problems and their socioeconomic root causes and impacts

Approval of TDA by national interministerial committees and binational steering committee by the end of Q7 including
Completed biophysical and socioeconomic characterization of the watershed and adjacent coastal areas
Institutional legal and policy analysis at national level and comparatively
Analysis of requirements to improve productive value chains and market access
Causal chain analysis clearly identifying root causes of major problems and priorities for SAP intervention

The Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis TDA is complete and approved
The TDA identifies the root causes as governance capacity and financial gaps The document prioritizes actions in control of sedimentation governance and capacity to make decisions based on international principles for binational water management

Approval of TDA by national interministerial committees and binational steering committee by the end of Q7 including
Completed biophysical and socioeconomic characterization of the watershed and adjacent coastal areas
Institutional legal and policy analysis at national level and comparatively
Analysis of requirements to improve productive value chains and market access
Causal chain analysis clearly identifying root causes of major problems and priorities for SAP intervention

The Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis TDA is complete and approved
The TDA identifies the root causes as governance capacity and financial gaps The document prioritizes actions in control of sedimentation governance and capacity to make decisions based on international principles for binational water management

description.narrative: Outcome 2 Strategic Action Program and binational governance mechanism for sustainable management of the Artibonito watershed negotiated and endorsed by the two countries
Agreement on binational governance framework to support SAP implementation operational by end of the project IW SP 3

comment.narrative: Baseline efforts to collaborate in specific aspects or areas for the management of the Artibonite watershed have not been comprehensive nor resulted in a functional binational initiative for effective cooperation action and joint management of this shared watershed
Permanent binational governance framework agreed to for SAP implementation with clearly defined institutional arrangements by Q15

Both Dominican Republic and Haiti have agreed on binational governance framework See page 7 as part of the SAP That agreement did not receive final endorsement
The binational steering committees which existed for the PROBINA and the Artibonito projects will cease to exist Even at the project level the structures were weak ceasing to meet at the hint of any binational problem The existing structure had not met in a bilateral forum since November 2012
The watershed management councils will continue in that role at the national level and will attempt to meet each other at the binational level A concept note has been prepared to develop a project to assist the watershed councils in their development
Permanent binational governance framework agreed to for SAP implementation with clearly defined institutional arrangements by Q15

Both Dominican Republic and Haiti have agreed on binational governance framework See page 7 as part of the SAP That agreement did not receive final endorsement
The binational steering committees which existed for the PROBINA and the Artibonito projects will cease to exist Even at the project level the structures were weak ceasing to meet at the hint of any binational problem The existing structure had not met in a bilateral forum since November 2012
The watershed management councils will continue in that role at the national level and will attempt to meet each other at the binational level A concept note has been prepared to develop a project to assist the watershed councils in their development

description.narrative: increase in awareness of importance of SLM and IWRM approaches in enabling the development needs of different sectors and stakeholder groups to be met

comment.narrative:
GEFUNDP LDCSIDS MSPs in global Portfolio Project will survey awareness of SLM at the national level
Level of awareness to be documented during inception phase of the project through a baseline Awareness Survey
Awareness of and the need for IWRM and SLM approaches is recognized as limited in both countries to small extension services and specialized units within line ministries Resource users largely unaware of integrated land and water principles

High level gt80 of responses to awareness survey by Governmental and NGO partners and 50 of general public demonstrate increased awareness by Q16
Information materials and knowledge building activities developed that respond to the needs of stakeholders in the watershed who range from municipal authorities to farmers with limited education to NGOs and CBOs by Q8 and widely disseminated by Q14
Building upon a CIDA project the primary education system will also be targeted by Q4

Actors at all levels are more aware of the Artibonite and how slm and IWRM are constructed by their accompaniment on the process There is however no baseline survey and final survey to indicate this Numerous radio spots were also presented over the airwaves but there is no bforeandafter snapshot for comparison

High level gt80 of responses to awareness survey by Governmental and NGO partners and 50 of general public demonstrate increased awareness by Q16
Information materials and knowledge building activities developed that respond to the needs of stakeholders in the watershed who range from municipal authorities to farmers with limited education to NGOs and CBOs by Q8 and widely disseminated by Q14
Building upon a CIDA project the primary education system will also be targeted by Q4

Actors at all levels are more aware of the Artibonite and how slm and IWRM are constructed by their accompaniment on the process There is however no baseline survey and final survey to indicate this Numerous radio spots were also presented over the airwaves but there is no bforeandafter snapshot for comparison

description.narrative: Nationallevel interministerial committees and binational steering committee established and strengthened IW SP3

comment.narrative: National Intersectoral committees GTI in DR and CIP in Haiti exist The capacity of these committees needs to be strengthened for participation in the TDASAP process
GTI and CIP fully engaged in the project with strengthened capacity for overseeing the TDASAP process for future implementation of the SAP by Q4

Support from the National Steering Committees and Binational Steering Committees was essential for the development drafting and adoption of the numerous project documents especially the SAP
Given the importance of these national structures it has been established in the SAP that the Binational Committee members will receive political and technical information from the National Committees of their respective countries The inclusion of the watershed management councils was specifically constructed to provide continuity in times of change
As mentioned above the binational steering committee which existed for the PROBINA and the Artibonito projects will cease to exist
The Management structure of the Artibonite River is a structure integrated to the Subcommittee of Environment and Agriculture of the Joint Bilateral Commission Reports of the meetings will be communicated by the Executive Secretary of the Joint Bilateral Commission to the Committee members and members of the National Committees and Watershed Councils It is possible that the committee will meet over the Artibonite in absence of the SAP document
National Committees should ensure the progress of the Strategic Action Plan on its territory and the progress of the National Action Plan for Watershed Management in their respective countries This will now shift to the Watershed management committees who will lobby their governmental partners to perform key functions such as measuring indicators
GTI and CIP fully engaged in the project with strengthened capacity for overseeing the TDASAP process for future implementation of the SAP by Q4

Support from the National Steering Committees and Binational Steering Committees was essential for the development drafting and adoption of the numerous project documents especially the SAP
Given the importance of these national structures it has been established in the SAP that the Binational Committee members will receive political and technical information from the National Committees of their respective countries The inclusion of the watershed management councils was specifically constructed to provide continuity in times of change
As mentioned above the binational steering committee which existed for the PROBINA and the Artibonito projects will cease to exist
The Management structure of the Artibonite River is a structure integrated to the Subcommittee of Environment and Agriculture of the Joint Bilateral Commission Reports of the meetings will be communicated by the Executive Secretary of the Joint Bilateral Commission to the Committee members and members of the National Committees and Watershed Councils It is possible that the committee will meet over the Artibonite in absence of the SAP document
National Committees should ensure the progress of the Strategic Action Plan on its territory and the progress of the National Action Plan for Watershed Management in their respective countries This will now shift to the Watershed management committees who will lobby their governmental partners to perform key functions such as measuring indicators

description.narrative: National Integrated Watershed Action Plans NIWAP that effectively mainstream SLM and IWRM approaches approved at the ministrylevel IW SP3 LD SP1

comment.narrative:
No agreed nor harmonized national integrated watershed management plans for the Artibonite have ever been developed even at national levels To date interventions have been fragmented site specific and largely uncoordinated
Specific actions at the national level for management of the watershed are limited in the two countries SLM and IWRM are not fully mainstreamed into national planning processes

The NIWAPs incorporate socioeconomic and biophysical factors to generate a robust planning tool that effectively enables each country to update landuse policies adopt IWRM reforms streamline IWRM and SLM approaches into productive sectors and facilitate stakeholder dialogue agencies municipalities private sector banking sector etc approved by Q9
NIWAPs will include an evaluation of the feasibility of the proposed actions and be compatible with UNCCD NAPS

The Strategic Action Program is complete but not endorsed see development objective
The NIWAP was completed in the Dominican Republic and circulated in 2 subregional events The NIWAP mainstreams actions in both SLM and IWRM It is the guiding plan for the Watershed Management Council of that country
In Haiti the NIWAP was developed in draft form and not approved by the completion date of the project It is also a guiding document but lacks specific information on WASH which is crucially important to Haiti given the cholera outbreaks An additional investment is necessary to advance the document through the final adjustment phase and socialize the document to a large audience before final approval

The NIWAPs incorporate socioeconomic and biophysical factors to generate a robust planning tool that effectively enables each country to update landuse policies adopt IWRM reforms streamline IWRM and SLM approaches into productive sectors and facilitate stakeholder dialogue agencies municipalities private sector banking sector etc approved by Q9
NIWAPs will include an evaluation of the feasibility of the proposed actions and be compatible with UNCCD NAPS

The Strategic Action Program is complete but not endorsed see development objective
The NIWAP was completed in the Dominican Republic and circulated in 2 subregional events The NIWAP mainstreams actions in both SLM and IWRM It is the guiding plan for the Watershed Management Council of that country
In Haiti the NIWAP was developed in draft form and not approved by the completion date of the project It is also a guiding document but lacks specific information on WASH which is crucially important to Haiti given the cholera outbreaks An additional investment is necessary to advance the document through the final adjustment phase and socialize the document to a large audience before final approval

description.narrative: Updated information available in the binational data and information management DIM system maintained through cooperation by specialized agencies in both countries LD SP1

comment.narrative: No binational data and information management system and limited sharing of data between the two countries Existing data are scattered among a number of institutions
Binational DIM system developed and fully operational and facilitates access to information for planning and decisionmaking in the watershed by the two countries by Q14

It was not possible for the Artibonito project to create a DIMS system because of the capacity gaps signaled in the TDA
Haiti has no water measurement capacity The DR has the capacity but does not have the budget to support yearly monitoring Neither country has the budget to cover recurrent costs Each country has acceptable geographic information management and now has the capacity to measure trends and changes
The SAP proposed a structure for information management and provisions for the free and open exchange of information and emergency response functions each of which is paramount to a DIM system and a technical structure joint body within the bilateral mixed commission
The Investment Plan Activity 4 includes the investments needed to measure changes in the watershed especially the hydrologic measurement in Haiti sources
The DR action plan has created a matrix in the SAP and the DR National Action Plan that identifi identifies topics within each protocol within the identified presents indicators for measurement
Therefore the architecture the indicators many with baselines and the costs of infrastructure were realized What is still unknown is the technical function of how information can be accessed and shared to support decisionmaking
Moreover 30 points were analyzed and reviewed for water quality in the INDRHI laboratories Additionally in the Neyta River samples were also taken to determine whether there are heavy metals as a result of exploration and mining works or naturally developed in the Haitian side The results show that these potential hazardous metalloids are below the critical limits
Binational DIM system developed and fully operational and facilitates access to information for planning and decisionmaking in the watershed by the two countries by Q14

It was not possible for the Artibonito project to create a DIMS system because of the capacity gaps signaled in the TDA
Haiti has no water measurement capacity The DR has the capacity but does not have the budget to support yearly monitoring Neither country has the budget to cover recurrent costs Each country has acceptable geographic information management and now has the capacity to measure trends and changes
The SAP proposed a structure for information management and provisions for the free and open exchange of information and emergency response functions each of which is paramount to a DIM system and a technical structure joint body within the bilateral mixed commission
The Investment Plan Activity 4 includes the investments needed to measure changes in the watershed especially the hydrologic measurement in Haiti sources
The DR action plan has created a matrix in the SAP and the DR National Action Plan that identifi identifies topics within each protocol within the identified presents indicators for measurement
Therefore the architecture the indicators many with baselines and the costs of infrastructure were realized What is still unknown is the technical function of how information can be accessed and shared to support decisionmaking
Moreover 30 points were analyzed and reviewed for water quality in the INDRHI laboratories Additionally in the Neyta River samples were also taken to determine whether there are heavy metals as a result of exploration and mining works or naturally developed in the Haitian side The results show that these potential hazardous metalloids are below the critical limits

description.narrative: Outcome 4 Increased capacity for longterm resource mobilization in support of NIWAP and SAP outcomes in support of IWRM and SLM approaches and sustainable livelihoods
The amount of funding commitments received from national and international government and private sources in support of actions detailed in the financing plan in US

comment.narrative:
Actions are funded specifically through government budgets whose of support based on investment needs of the watershed is undetermined and recognized as very low in comparison to needs and as expressed by 2008 HDI for DR
Bilateral support of approximately 40 Million USD from 2009 through 2011 committed to the Artibonite watershed

Initial funding commitments to support SAP implementation from all sources for 20 of the value of the financing gap as outlined in the financing plan for the period 20122016
Increase in government budgetary allocations in support of sustainable activities in the watershed by 20 over base year 2008 in US dollars by Q16
Increase in Biand multilateral donor activity to support the Artibonite by 20 over base year 2008 by Q16

Funding commitments from parallel agencies totaled 78 Million dollars US at the time the study was developed These were in IDB Haiti 55M WB Haiti 75M for the Artibonite Boucle Centre and 2 Million in EU support to Migration commerce and small grants The Gap of the SAP is calculated at 120 M US
The project management unit did meet with all major donors to promote investments in the watershed but was not able to advance into direct support to parters to fund their initiatives
The Watershed Management Councils will now continue to promote the investments and capture funding following a capacity building process

Initial funding commitments to support SAP implementation from all sources for 20 of the value of the financing gap as outlined in the financing plan for the period 20122016
Increase in government budgetary allocations in support of sustainable activities in the watershed by 20 over base year 2008 in US dollars by Q16
Increase in Biand multilateral donor activity to support the Artibonite by 20 over base year 2008 by Q16

Funding commitments from parallel agencies totaled 78 Million dollars US at the time the study was developed These were in IDB Haiti 55M WB Haiti 75M for the Artibonite Boucle Centre and 2 Million in EU support to Migration commerce and small grants The Gap of the SAP is calculated at 120 M US
The project management unit did meet with all major donors to promote investments in the watershed but was not able to advance into direct support to parters to fund their initiatives
The Watershed Management Councils will now continue to promote the investments and capture funding following a capacity building process

description.narrative: increase in funding and the diversity of funding sources LD SP1

comment.narrative:
Funding for ontheground actions through 2 recognized sources
Governments disburse fund actions in the Artibonite but these are not in response to any longrange investment plan The percent contribution of these in relation to the needs of the watershed is not known
Bilateral support of approximately 40 Million USD from 2009 through 2011 committed to the Artibonite watershed
At least 2 new financial mechanisms in addition to government budgets or donor projects for funding of ontheground investments determined feasible for SAP implementation by Q14
The diversity of funding sources has not changed during the period of evaluation
At least 2 new financial mechanisms in addition to government budgets or donor projects for funding of ontheground investments determined feasible for SAP implementation by Q14
The diversity of funding sources has not changed during the period of evaluation

description.narrative: Options to increase access by rural producers to formal credit facilities are determined to support credit programs for SAP implementation LD SP1

comment.narrative:
Limited capacity for longterm resource mobilization and poor access to credit by farmers for sustainable land and water management practices
Many experiences in cooperatives with small business and real estate sectors Farm loans have generally decapitalized with income groups similar to those in the Aribonite

Building upon the lessons learned a plan to mitigate the risks associated with agriculture loans is developed and presented to financiers by Q14
Watershed investment plans provide the basis for financing SAP implementation and ontheground actions within the watershed by Q14
Financial mechanisms and resources to support the investment plan identified by Q13

There were no changes in this indicator The work with UNDPART Gold did not materialize
The resources of the component were directed towards developing the watershed investment Plan

Building upon the lessons learned a plan to mitigate the risks associated with agriculture loans is developed and presented to financiers by Q14
Watershed investment plans provide the basis for financing SAP implementation and ontheground actions within the watershed by Q14
Financial mechanisms and resources to support the investment plan identified by Q13

There were no changes in this indicator The work with UNDPART Gold did not materialize
The resources of the component were directed towards developing the watershed investment Plan

description.narrative: Watershed Investment Plans determine the financial objectives and targets for SAP implementation and ontheground investments to increase cover in the Artibonite IW SP3 LD SP1

comment.narrative:
No strategic investment programs for productive sectors coupled with longterm projections to increase effective cover and increase water yield in the watershed
Partial investment planning in the DR and Haitian coffee sectors with no agreedupon investments for setting long range targets for expansion
Market studies for fruits and vegetables completed for Haiti with no agreed upon longrange targets
Energy and livestock management sectors do not have consolidated information or longrange targets for investment

Investment plans to be integrated into the SAP that promote SLM and IWRM and extend cover in the form of trees pasture and fruit tree plantations through economic development of the coffee forestry livestock management fruit agriculture energy and transportation infrastructure
For each sector targets for expansion a financing gap analysis and action plan for environmentally sound sectorexpansion in biophysically appropriate areas of the watershed

Investment plans were developed for Infrastructure and irrigation energy Reforestation and Agrolivestock management
The project was not able to develop an investment plan for water and sanitation facilities an important next step
The investment plans were included in the NIWAP in each country and in the SAP document The priority investments and geographic locations is described for a 10 year period
The investments and their priority level was a product of a participative process
